elements.content: Five novel lanthanide−organic frameworks: [Ln(NTA)(H2O)2]·H2O (Ln = Eu (1)) and [Ln(NTA)(H2O)] (Ln = Tb (2), Ho (3, 4), and Tm (5); NTA = nitrilotriacetate anion) have been constructed by a rational synthetic strategy. 1 and 5 were successfully obtained by tuning the number of coordinated water molecules to lanthanide ions under different temperatures, while 2 and 3 were prepared under the same synthetic temperature as that of 5. Structural analyses indicate that they belong to three different space groups. 1 displays an irregular two-dimensional (2D) lattice consisting of alternative L- and R-type single-chain helixes, and both 2 and 3 are 2D double layer structures, while 4 and 5 are porous three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Surprisingly, although 3 and 4 have identical molecular formulas, their structures exhibit significant differences originating from different pH values used in the synthesis. Interestingly, one-dimensional (1D) channels exist in the 3D frameworks of 4 and 5; each channel is fabricated through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The explorations of magnetic properties of 2 and 5 were carried out. The luminescent investigations reveal that 2 exhibits characteristic luminescence of Tb3+, and the lifetime of the transition 5D4 → 7F5 is about 0.78 ms when excited at λex = 296 nm.

The luminescent investigations reveal that 2 exhibits characteristic luminescence of Tb3+, and the lifetime of the transition 5D4 → 7F5 is about 0.78 ms when excited at λex = 296 nm.

elements.content: Five novel lanthanide−organic frameworks were constructed by the rational synthetic strategy, and their structures change from an irregular two-dimensional (2D) lattice to a 2D double-layer and to a three-dimensional porous motif with charming one-dimensional channels fabricated through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The explorations of magnetic and luminescent properties were also carried out.
elements.clean_text: Five novel lanthanide-organic frameworks were constructed by the rational synthetic strategy, and their structures change from an irregular two-dimensional (2D) lattice to a 2D double-layer and to a three-dimensional porous motif with charming one-dimensional channels fabricated through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The explorations of magnetic and luminescent properties were also carried out.

elements.content: The design and construction of lanthanide−organic frameworks have received extensive attention due to their unique topological structures and fascinating chemical/physical properties. The higher coordination number and more variable nature of the lanthanide coordination sphere, as well as interesting luminescent and magnetic properties of lanthanide complexes, have prompted their applications in the fields of porosity, luminescence, magnetism, and catalytic activity. Therefore, many spectacular lanthanide−organic frameworks have been well documented recently. However, compared with numerous transition metal−organic frameworks reported previously, the fabrications of lanthanide-organic frameworks have large challenges. The relative paucity of research on Ln-based counterparts may result, at least partially, from the features of the high and various coordination numbers, which favors the formation of condensed structures. Namely, lanthanide ions have been investigated specifically for their features to form higher connectivity nodes in frameworks. The absence of rigidity for the lanthanide coordination sphere can be detrimental for the generation of porosity, because it can permit structural distortion of the framework. As a result, most lanthanide−organic frameworks reported either are nonporous or display only solvent sorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of lanthanide-organic frameworks have received extensive attention due to their unique topological structures and fascinating chemical/physical properties. The higher coordination number and more variable nature of the lanthanide coordination sphere, as well as interesting luminescent and magnetic properties of lanthanide complexes, have prompted their applications in the fields of porosity, luminescence, magnetism, and catalytic activity. Therefore, many spectacular lanthanide-organic frameworks have been well documented recently. However, compared with numerous transition metal-organic frameworks reported previously, the fabrications of lanthanide-organic frameworks have large challenges. The relative paucity of research on Ln-based counterparts may result, at least partially, from the features of the high and various coordination numbers, which favors the formation of condensed structures. Namely, lanthanide ions have been investigated specifically for their features to form higher connectivity nodes in frameworks. The absence of rigidity for the lanthanide coordination sphere can be detrimental for the generation of porosity, because it can permit structural distortion of the framework. As a result, most lanthanide-organic frameworks reported either are nonporous or display only solvent sorption.

elements.content: On the other hand, it is well established that hydrothermal synthesis is an effective and promising method for growing crystals of numerous inorganic compounds, and a variety of transition metal coordination polymers were successfully synthesized by employing this approach. Furthermore, our previous work also shows that the special method is proper for preparation of lanthanide-based porous coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, it is well established that hydrothermal synthesis is an effective and promising method for growing crystals of numerous inorganic compounds, and a variety of transition metal coordination polymers were successfully synthesized by employing this approach. Furthermore, our previous work also shows that the special method is proper for preparation of lanthanide-based porous coordination polymers.

elements.content: In this contribution, we selected H3NTA as a multifunctional ligand and employed hydrothermal methods to successfully obtain five lanthanide-based coordination polymers: [Ln(NTA)(H2O)2]·H2O (Ln = Eu (1)) and [Ln(NTA)(H2O)] (Ln = Tb (2), Ho (3 and 4), and Tm (5); NTA = nitrilotriacetate anion). Their structures change from irregular 2D lattice to 2D double-layer and to 3D porous motif. Compound 1 is an irregular 2D lattice motif consisting of alternative L- and R-type single-chain helixes; both 2 and 3 are 2D double layer structures, while compounds 4 and 5 display 3D porous frameworks, which have 1D channels fabricated through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The explorations of magnetic properties for 2 and 5 were carried out. Compound 2 exhibits luminescence characteristic of Tb3+, and the lifetime of transition 5D4 → 7D5 when excited at λex = 296 nm is about 0.78 ms.

Their structures change from irregular 2D lattice to 2D double-layer and to 3D porous motif. Compound 1 is an irregular 2D lattice motif consisting of alternative L- and R-type single-chain helixes; both 2 and 3 are 2D double layer structures, while compounds 4 and 5 display 3D porous frameworks, which have 1D channels fabricated through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The explorations of magnetic properties for 2 and 5 were carried out. Compound 2 exhibits luminescence characteristic of Tb3+, and the lifetime of transition 5D4 → 7D5 when excited at λex = 296 nm is about 0.78 ms.

elements.content: Actually, from the entropic point of view, synthesis at a higher temperature could reduce terminal ancillary ligands, such as water or other solvent molecules, and result in the generation of open frameworks with higher dimensionality. In our previous work, the idea has been employed to successfully synthesize nanotubular 3D open frameworks by reducing ancillary coordinated water on Mn2+ ions under the high temperature. Namely, under proper conditions, the significant structure transformation may be realized by tuning the number of coordinated water molecules on metal ions. However, the similar investigations on the system containing lanthanide ions have not been reported so far. Therefore, we wondered if the structures of lanthanide-based complexes were altered by only tuning coordinated water on lanthanide ions. With this aim, 1 and 5 were obtained by the following synthetic strategy (see Scheme ). In fact, the 3D coordination polymer [Eu(NTA)(H2O)] (here named 1a) has been obtained by Jin et al. under hydrothermal conditions at 150 °C, and in 1a only one water molecule coordinated to one Eu3+ ion. Inspired by this, through employing hydrothermal synthesis of a lower temperature, unique 2D polymer 1 [Eu(NTA)(H2O)2] has been obtained with two coordinated water molecules located on each Eu3+ ion. Additionally, 1D chain-like polymer [Tm(NTA)(H2O)2]·2H2O (here named 5a) has also been prepared at room temperature, and two water molecules coordinated to each Tm3+ ion in 5a. According to the idea mentioned above, using the hydrothermal method with a temperature of 160 °C, the porous 3D polymer 5 [Tm(NTA)(H2O)] with an interweaving triple-stranded helicate is synthesized, and expectedly, the number of coordinated water molecules to the Tm3+ ion decreases from 2 in 5a to 1 in 5. Interestingly, the significant change between 1 and 1a, together with 5 and 5a only originated from altering water molecules connected to metal ions.

elements.content: All chemicals are analytical grade. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were obtained at the Institute of Elemental Organic Chemistry, Nankai University. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer on KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analysis was done under nitrogen atmosphere at a scan state of 10.0 K/min using NETZSCH TG 209. The emission spectra in the visible region were measured on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Characterization

All chemicals are analytical grade. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were obtained at the Institute of Elemental Organic Chemistry, Nankai University. The FT-IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrophotometer on KBr disks. Thermogravimetric analysis was done under nitrogen atmosphere at a scan state of 10.0 K/min using NETZSCH TG 209. The emission spectra in the visible region were measured on a Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Crystallographic data of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were collected with a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD area detector, and data of 3 was collected with a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD area detector. Both detectors were equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo KR radiation (λ = 0.7173 Å). Structures were solved by direct methods with the SHELXTL-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques against F 2 with the SHELXTL-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically. Crystallographic data for the five compounds are listed in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Crystallographic data of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were collected with a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD area detector, and data of 3 was collected with a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD area detector. Both detectors were equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo KR radiation (λ = 0.7173 Å). Structures were solved by direct methods with the SHELXTL-97 program and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques against F 2 with the SHELXTL-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically. Crystallographic data for the five compounds are listed in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table .

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 5 were successfully obtained by changing the number of water molecules coordinated to lanthanide ions under different temperatures, while the syntheses of 2 and 3 were carried out with the same synthetic temperature as that of 5. It should be noted that only the pH value is different during the preparation of 3 and 4, indicating that the pH value may have an important effect on the structural assembly of series of [Ln-NTA] compounds. Unfortunately, it has been not observed so far that the structures of other [Ln-NTA] compounds change under different pH values, although many efforts were done.
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

Syntheses

Compounds 1 and 5 were successfully obtained by changing the number of water molecules coordinated to lanthanide ions under different temperatures, while the syntheses of 2 and 3 were carried out with the same synthetic temperature as that of 5. It should be noted that only the pH value is different during the preparation of 3 and 4, indicating that the pH value may have an important effect on the structural assembly of series of [Ln-NTA] compounds. Unfortunately, it has been not observed so far that the structures of other [Ln-NTA] compounds change under different pH values, although many efforts were done.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction results reveal that compound 1 belongs to the monoclinic system with space group Pbca. Six OCOO- atoms, one nitrogen atom, and two Owater atoms complete the nine-coordinate environment of Eu3+, which conforms closely to a slightly distorted tricapped trigonal prism (Figure ). O5, O3, O6A and O1, O4A, O7 atoms construct the top and bottom planes of the trigonal prism, respectively, and O8, O5A, and N1 atoms act as three caps of the prism. The NTA molecule as a tetradentate (O1, O3, O5 and N1 atoms) ligand chelates to the Eu1 center. The Eu−O bonds are in the range 2.337−2.665 Å, and the Eu−N distance is 2.630 Å. Interestingly, in the [100] direction adjacent Eu3+ ions were linked by carboxylic O atoms to generate a single-chain helicate motif with a pitch of 8.113 Å (Figure ). These helixes displayed either left-hand (L) or right-hand (R) structures; however, the L- and R-type single-chain helixes are arrayed alternatively, indicative of an achirality feature of 1, confirmed by the achiral space group of 1. It should be noted that adjacent helicate chains were further bridged by carboxylic groups along the [010] direction, resulting in a slightly distorted 2D lattice (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Single crystal X-ray diffraction results reveal that compound 1 belongs to the monoclinic system with space group Pbca. Six OCOO- atoms, one nitrogen atom, and two Owater atoms complete the nine-coordinate environment of Eu3+, which conforms closely to a slightly distorted tricapped trigonal prism (Figure ). O5, O3, O6A and O1, O4A, O7 atoms construct the top and bottom planes of the trigonal prism, respectively, and O8, O5A, and N1 atoms act as three caps of the prism. The NTA molecule as a tetradentate (O1, O3, O5 and N1 atoms) ligand chelates to the Eu1 center. The Eu-O bonds are in the range 2.337-2.665 Å, and the Eu-N distance is 2.630 Å. Interestingly, in the [100] direction adjacent Eu3+ ions were linked by carboxylic O atoms to generate a single-chain helicate motif with a pitch of 8.113 Å (Figure ). These helixes displayed either left-hand (L) or right-hand (R) structures; however, the L- and R-type single-chain helixes are arrayed alternatively, indicative of an achirality feature of 1, confirmed by the achiral space group of 1. It should be noted that adjacent helicate chains were further bridged by carboxylic groups along the [010] direction, resulting in a slightly distorted 2D lattice (Figure ).

elements.content: The crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 are isomorphous, belonging to the monoclinic system with space group P21 /n. Compound 2 as an example is described here. In 2, each Tb3+ ion is eight coordinated (Figure a). Six OCOO- atoms, one nitrogen atom, and one Owater atom establish the coordinated sphere of the Tb3+ ion, which is closed to a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prism (Figure ). O5C, O3, O2A and O1, O4B, O6 atoms form the top and bottom planes of the trigonal prism, respectively, and O7 and N1 atoms act as two caps of the prism. Like that in 1, each NTA molecule in 2 still acts as a tetradentate ligand and chelates to one Tb3+ center. The Tb−O distances are in the range from 2.334 to 2.400 Å, and the Tb−N distance is 2.613 Å. Interestingly, eight [Tb(NTA)] subunits were linked through the carboxyl group bridges to form a cuboid motif with Tb3+ ions as vertexes (Figure ), in which the separations between neighboring Tb3+ ions were 6.596, 6.656, and 6.782 Å, respectively. The cuboid motif as a repeating unit was further assembled in the ac plane into a 2D double-layer structure (Figure ).

elements.content: The crystal structures of compounds 4 and 5 are isomorphous, belonging to orthorhombic system with space group P212121. Compound 5 as an example is depicted here. Although the molecular formulas of compounds 4 and 5 are completely similar to those of 2 and 3, their structures significantly differ from those of 2 and 3. The structure of compound 5 is shown in Figure . Six OCOO- atoms, one nitrogen atom, and one Owater atom complete the eight-coordinated sphere of the Tm3+ ion, which is closed to a bicapped trigonal prism. O7, O1A, O2 and O3B, O4, O6 atoms form the top and bottom planes of the trigonal prism, respectively, while O5 (water molecule) and N1 atoms act as two caps of the prism (Figure ). The Tm−O bonds fall in the range from 2.236 to 2.369 Å, and the Tm−N distance is 2.606 Å. Adjacent [Tm(NTA)] units were linked by carboxylic group bridges to give rise to an ordered 3D lanthanide-organic framework (Figure ) with 1D channels in [100] direction. The cross section of each channel is made up of 6 Tm3+ ions, 6 C atoms and 12 O atoms, forming a 24-membered ring of [Tm6C6O12], the size of the channel is about 7.5 × 3.7 Å2 (Figure ). Actually, the six Tm3+ ions are not coplanar, displaying a chairlike shape or trigonal antiprism with an off-set angle of about 60°. Interestingly for the wall of any channel, the Tm3+ ions are connected by carboxylic groups from NTA ligands to fabricate a right- and left-handed triple-stranded helical motif with a pitch of 22.75 Å. Namely, the wall of each channel is constructed through interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes (Figure ).

elements.content: Because of different synthetic temperatures, the number of coordinated water molecules located on the Eu3+ ion in 1 is two, but only one in 1a, and the little divergence should be responsible for the giant difference of structures between 1 and 1a. The same phenomenon was observed between 5 and 5a, and the above explanation was also available for the significant differences in structure between them. Surprisingly, compounds 3 and 4 have the same molecular formula and the coordination number of lanthanide ions; however, due to the subtle difference of coordination modes of NTA, the structure changes from 2D double-layer in 3 to 3D porous framework in 4. More importantly, the walls of the channel existed in 4 and/or 5 consisting of the interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. Comparably, although many single-, double-, and multistranded helical structures together with circular and cylindrical ones have been prepared hitherto. In particular, lanthanide ions have been well explored to design and prepare more complicated and multistranded helicate complexes by taking advantage of their variable and high coordination number. However, it should be noted that the majority of reported helicate chains in length were not infinite but finite, and the infinite multistranded helicate complex containing lanthanide ions is rather rare.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of Structures

Because of different synthetic temperatures, the number of coordinated water molecules located on the Eu3+ ion in 1 is two, but only one in 1a, and the little divergence should be responsible for the giant difference of structures between 1 and 1a. The same phenomenon was observed between 5 and 5a, and the above explanation was also available for the significant differences in structure between them. Surprisingly, compounds 3 and 4 have the same molecular formula and the coordination number of lanthanide ions; however, due to the subtle difference of coordination modes of NTA, the structure changes from 2D double-layer in 3 to 3D porous framework in 4. More importantly, the walls of the channel existed in 4 and/or 5 consisting of the interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. Comparably, although many single-, double-, and multistranded helical structures together with circular and cylindrical ones have been prepared hitherto. In particular, lanthanide ions have been well explored to design and prepare more complicated and multistranded helicate complexes by taking advantage of their variable and high coordination number. However, it should be noted that the majority of reported helicate chains in length were not infinite but finite, and the infinite multistranded helicate complex containing lanthanide ions is rather rare.

elements.content: It is well-known that ligand NTA possesses various coordination modes, which is confirmed by this work and the literature. The main coordination modes are shown in Scheme . The mode B exists in compound 1, and the mode C occurs in compounds 2 and 3, as well as the mode D was displayed in 4 and 5, while other modes A and E were observed in reported work. Only a very small difference exists between modes C and D; that is, the NTA ligand chelated to the lanthanide center bridged adjacent metal ions through carboxylic groups with different angles. Interestingly, for 3 and 4, their molecular formulas and the coordination number of lanthanide ions are completely identical. However, the transformation from the 2D double-layer in 3 to 3D porous framework in 4 only originated from the extremely subtle differences between modes C and D.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes of NTA

It is well-known that ligand NTA possesses various coordination modes, which is confirmed by this work and the literature. The main coordination modes are shown in Scheme . The mode B exists in compound 1, and the mode C occurs in compounds 2 and 3, as well as the mode D was displayed in 4 and 5, while other modes A and E were observed in reported work. Only a very small difference exists between modes C and D; that is, the NTA ligand chelated to the lanthanide center bridged adjacent metal ions through carboxylic groups with different angles. Interestingly, for 3 and 4, their molecular formulas and the coordination number of lanthanide ions are completely identical. However, the transformation from the 2D double-layer in 3 to 3D porous framework in 4 only originated from the extremely subtle differences between modes C and D.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of these compounds were investigated at room temperature. Under the ultraviolet radiation, only compound 2 has strong green luminescence, and unfortunately, the emission of 1 was not observed, which indicates that NTA ligands can effectively sensitize the luminescence of Tb3+ ions rather than Eu3+. The emission spectra are given in Figure . When the sample is excited at 296 nm, four luminescent peaks are observed from 491 to 623 nm. They are 491 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 548 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 586 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 623 nm (5D4 → 7F3), of which two intense emission bands are located at 491 and 546 nm, respectively. The lifetime of transition 5D4 → 7F5 is 0.78 ms for 2.

Luminescent Properties of Complex 2 

The solid-state luminescence properties of these compounds were investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra are given in Figure . When the sample is excited at 296 nm, four luminescent peaks are observed from 491 to 623 nm. They are 491 nm (5D4 → 7F6), 548 nm (5D4 → 7F5), 586 nm (5D4 → 7F4), and 623 nm (5D4 → 7F3), of which two intense emission bands are located at 491 and 546 nm, respectively. elements.content: For the majority of Ln3+ ions, due to the large orbital angular momentum, it is well-known that the isolation of the single-ion magnetic anisotropy from the exchange contribution in the analysis of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility is a largely unachieved task. Theoretically, due to the interelectronic repulsion and spin−orbit coupling, the 4fn configuration may be split into 2S+1 L J spectroscopic levels. Each of these levels may be further split into Stark sublevels by the crystal field perturbation. All Stark sublevels are thermally populated at room temperature. When the temperature is lowered, a depopulation of these sublevels occurs, and consequently χM Ln T decreases (χM Ln stands for the molar magnetic susceptibility of Ln ions) with decreasing temperature. When the Ln3+ interacts with another paramagnetic species, including Ln3+ itself, the temperature dependence of χM T is due to both the variation of χM Ln T and the coupling between the Ln3+ and the second spin carrier. As a result, the nature of the interactions between Ln3+ ions cannot be unambiguously deduced when χM T value decreases with lowering temperature. On the contrary, when the χM T value increases with the decreasing temperature, it is certain that magnetic interaction between adjacent Ln3+ ions shows ferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 2 and 5 

For the majority of Ln3+ ions, due to the large orbital angular momentum, it is well-known that the isolation of the single-ion magnetic anisotropy from the exchange contribution in the analysis of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility is a largely unachieved task. Theoretically, due to the interelectronic repulsion and spin-orbit coupling, the 4fn configuration may be split into 2S+1 L  J  spectroscopic levels. Each of these levels may be further split into Stark sublevels by the crystal field perturbation. All Stark sublevels are thermally populated at room temperature. When the temperature is lowered, a depopulation of these sublevels occurs, and consequently χM Ln T decreases (χM Ln stands for the molar magnetic susceptibility of Ln ions) with decreasing temperature. When the Ln3+ interacts with another paramagnetic species, including Ln3+ itself, the temperature dependence of χM T is due to both the variation of χM Ln T and the coupling between the Ln3+ and the second spin carrier. As a result, the nature of the interactions between Ln3+ ions cannot be unambiguously deduced when χM T value decreases with lowering temperature. On the contrary, when the χM T value increases with the decreasing temperature, it is certain that magnetic interaction between adjacent Ln3+ ions shows ferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of the 2 and 5 were measured in the temperature range from 2 to 300 K and under 1000 Oe field, as shown in Figure . The value of χM T of 2 at 300 K is 11.74 cm3 K mol−1, which is close to the theoretical value of 11.81 cm3 K mol−1 expected for one Tb3+ ion in the 7 F 6 ground state (g = 3/2). The value of χM T of 5 at 300 K is 7.14 cm3 K mol−1, which is slightly lower than the expected value of 7.15 cm3 K mol−1 for one Tm3+ ion in the 3 H 4 ground state (g = 7/6). The χM T value for 2 and 5 slowly decreases on cooling and reaches a minimum value of 4.99 cm3 K mol−1 for 2 and 5.61 cm3 K mol−1 for 5 at 2 K. On the basis of the reason mentioned above, we are not sure that antiferromagnetic coupling exists between adjacent Tb3+ in 2 or adjacent Tm3+ in 5, because any weak exchange interaction within the structure is masked by crystal field effects, and no conclusions can therefore be drawn about the nature of magnetic interactions in 2 and 5.

elements.content: Five novel lanthanide−organic frameworks 1−5 have been constructed by a rational synthetic strategy. 1 displays an irregular 2D lattice consisting of alternative L- and R-type single-chain helixes, and both 2 and 3 are 2D double layer structures, while 4 and 5 are porous 3D frameworks. This is the first time to observe large structure changes only by tuning the number of coordinated water molecules to lanthanide ions in constructing lanthanide−organic frameworks (such as 1 and 5). Surprisingly, 3 and 4 exhibit huge difference in their structures, although they have identical molecular formulas. Interestingly, a 1D channel exists in the 3D frameworks of 4 and 5, and each channel consists of interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The luminescent investigations reveal that 2 exhibits luminescence characteristic of Tb3+. This work is hoped to afford inspiration for the fabrication of lanthanide-based frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Five novel lanthanide-organic frameworks 1-5 have been constructed by a rational synthetic strategy. 1 displays an irregular 2D lattice consisting of alternative L- and R-type single-chain helixes, and both 2 and 3 are 2D double layer structures, while 4 and 5 are porous 3D frameworks. This is the first time to observe large structure changes only by tuning the number of coordinated water molecules to lanthanide ions in constructing lanthanide-organic frameworks (such as 1 and 5). Surprisingly, 3 and 4 exhibit huge difference in their structures, although they have identical molecular formulas. Interestingly, a 1D channel exists in the 3D frameworks of 4 and 5, and each channel consists of interweaving left- and right-hand triple-stranded helixes. The luminescent investigations reveal that 2 exhibits luminescence characteristic of Tb3+. This work is hoped to afford inspiration for the fabrication of lanthanide-based frameworks.

[Eu(NTA)(H2O)2]·H2O (1): A mixture of H3NTA (0.3 mmol), EuCl3 (0.3 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) with a pH value of 6, which was adjusted using triethylamine, was placed in a 20 mL autoclave, then heated at 120 °C for three days, and then cooled to room temperature at the speed of 1.5 °C/h. The colorless block crystals were obtained in 42% yield based on Eu. Elemental analysis for [Eu(NTA)(H2O)2]·H2O. Calc: C, 18.28; H, 3.07; N 3.55. Found: C, 18.51; H, 3.84; N, 3.79.
